data.title: 21st Century Span: The New Tappan Zee Bridge
data.meta_description: The Tappan Zee, the longest bridge in New York, opened in 1955 and was designed to last 50 years. Now work has begun on a bridge to replace it, one that will also be the widest in the world by some measures. Articles in this series are chronicling the construction of the new double-spanned bridge and the people building it.
data.text:
First Horizontal Piece Is Placed Along the New Tappan Zee Bridge

Huge steel girders were lifted into place near the bridge’s Rockland County side; dozens more will be added before the bridge can be open to traffic at the end of 2016.

By

Doubling Up on Long Johns and Gloves to Keep Tappan Zee Bridge Project Going

Even during a winter that feels historic in its unrelenting bite, work on the $3.9 billion replacement for the bridge is proceeding.

By

For New Tappan Zee, Questions Persist Over How High the Tolls Will Climb

The discount afforded by one of the New York City area’s great travel bargains — crossing the Hudson River on the Tappan Zee Bridge — is likely to shrink, but no one can say by how much.

By

This Time, Tappan Zee Bridge Project Proceeds With Neighbors in Mind

The new Hudson River crossing is being built with more sensitivity to the needs and feelings of people living nearby, unlike when the current bridge went up in the ’50s.

By
